name: Rebibbia prison
desc:
In Rome, there are two main prisons: Regina Cœli, in the city centre near Trastevere, and Rebibbia, in the Ponte Mammolo suburb. This prison, which had the particularity of being mixed, was located a few blocks from the Pasolini family's flat.

In the poem The Tears of the Excavator, which is in The Ashes of Gramsci, Pier Paolo Pasolini nostalgically evokes Ponte Mammolo and Rebibbia, the prison representing, by metonymy, the proletarian quarter where he lived.

I undress, in one of a thousand rooms
where one sleeps, via Fonteiana.
You can erode everything, time: hopes,
passions. But not these pure forms
of life... It is with them
that man becomes confused, come to the end
of experience and confidence
in this world... Ah, days of Rebibbia,
that I thought lost in the light
of necessity, and which I discover so free!

Pasolini would come up with the idea for Mamma Roma reading an article in the press about the dramatic death of Marcello Elisei, a young prisoner at Rebibbia who died tied to a bed in isolation. And in 2012, the Taviani brothers filmed Caesar Must Die, winner of the Golden Bear at the 2012 Berlin Festival, in this prison of Rebibbia.
